Author: gress
Content:
We're not machines at all.

Edit: since I'm being downvoted, I'll qualify this.

Machines are a human invention. They are something we have design, and we design them for predictability. The concept of a machine failing or breaking down is only meaningful in reference to the behavior specified in the design, or intent of the designer. It should be noted that the design is valid to the extent that the designer understands the environment in which the machine will operate.

Unless you believe in intelligent design, we are not constructed according to a design. We are part of the environment in which machines operate, but we are not machines ourselves. Using the metaphor of a machine to describe our bodies is never going to be truly valid, because we will never have access to the design, because there is no design.

Author: iandanforth
Content: You don't have to die. We are not magical machines, just very complex ones. While the phrase 'curing cancer' does not capture the scope of the task, I object to the suggestion of cancer or any other disease based deaths inevitability.

Author: personlurking
Content: At about 17m40s into the film Code 46 (from 2003), there's a scene in a bar/club where Tim Robbins tells the female lead that she should take a virus (little thing you place on your tongue) to sing on the stage in the bar. In the film, these 24-hr viruses of the future allow people to do various things like be empathetic, speak Mandarin or sing with perfect pitch.

Author: tgflynn
Content:
I've noticed the same thing to some extent.

Of course topics like Haskell vs. Erlang or machine learning apps or libraries come up regularly here so there's nothing very unusual about that.

Beyond that let me propose a somewhat unconventional explanation, at least one I don't think I've heard before in quite this form.

Where do you you think your ideas come from ? Clearly they come from your brain, whose state is largely determined by your experiences. I think there are many people, perhaps increasingly many, who tend to share many of the same experiences. One example is that people who studied CS in University were probably exposed to many very similar ideas. Moreover people who get much of their news from articles posted on HN or other popular web sites are again being exposed to very similar ideas. All of this leads to many people sharing quite similar brain states and hence coming up with similar ideas.

Author: quinnchr
Content: Do you have any sources for your claims? Because pretty much all data I can find indicates the exact opposite of what you're saying.

Author: chippy
Content:
"I expect that people are paid to work on OSM"

For the actual map: not really - it's only been done in certain developing world situations where people cannot devote their time for free. Also, data has been added from commercial companies and administrations.

For your example - if it's a western university I would imagine it to be one or two people based in the university. Does the university have a Geography Department? How about a Computing Department?

Have a look at Bing aerial imagery - does it look like that building could be traced easily from it? It would take about a minute I'd guess.
